name: Al - Khwarizmi
intro: Al-Khwarizmi, a 9th-century Persian mathematician, is known as the "Father of Algebra." His book "Kitab al-Jabr wa al-Muqabala" introduced systematic methods for solving equations and laid the foundation for algebra. He also made contributions to trigonometry and the adoption of Arabic numerals, shaping the development of mathematics.
achievement: The term algorithm is derived from the algorism, the technique of performing arithmetic with Hindu–Arabic numerals popularised by al-Khwarizmi in his book On the Calculation with Hindu Numerals.

name: Banū Mūsā Brothers
intro: The Banū Mūsā brothers, Ahmad, Muhammad, and al-Hasan, were a group of three Persian scholars who lived during the 9th century in Baghdad, which was then part of the Abbasid Caliphate. They were renowned for their contributions to various fields, including mathematics, mechanics, and engineering. The brothers authored several influential works, such as the "Book of Ingenious Devices," which covered a wide range of subjects like automata, geometry, and astronomical instruments. Their works were instrumental in preserving and advancing scientific knowledge from the Hellenistic and Persian traditions.
achievement: Three brothers who wrote the Book of Ingenious Devices, describing what appears to be the first programmable machine, an automatic flute player.

name: Al - Jazari
intro: Ismail al-Jazari was a polymath who lived during the Islamic Golden Age (roughly 8th to 14th centuries). He was an inventor, mechanical engineer, artisan, artist and mathematician who wrote an influential book called "The Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices" in which he described 100 mechanical devices, 80 of which were trick vessels of various kinds, along with instructions on how to construct them
achievement: Invented programmable machines, including programmable humanoid robots, and the castle clock, an astronomical clock considered the first programmable analog computer.

name: Ramon Llull
intro: Ramon Llull (1232–1316), also known as Raymond Lull or Lully, was a mathematician, polymath, philosopher, logician, Franciscan tertiary, and writer from the Kingdom of Majorca. He is best known for his Ars Combinatoria, a method aimed at discovering truth by combining basic elements of knowledge through a systematic process.
achievement: Designed multiple symbolic representations machines, and pioneered notions of symbolic representation and manipulation to produce knowledge—both of which were major influences on Leibniz.

name: Blaise Pascal
intro: Blaise Pascal was a French mathematician, physicist, inventor, writer, and Catholic theologian who lived in the 17th century. He made several important contributions to mathematics and physical sciences, and also invented the Pascaline, an early mechanical calculator.
achievement: Pascal is famous for his contributions to probability theory and his work with Pascal's Triangle which is used in binomial expansion. Pascal is also known for inventing an early digital calculator, a syringe, a hydraulic press, and the roulette wheel.He also invented the mechanical calculator.

name: Gottfried Leibniz
achievement: Made advances in symbolic logic, such as the Calculus ratiocinator, that were heavily influential on Gottlob Frege. He anticipated later developments in first-order predicate calculus, which were crucial for the theoretical foundations of computer science.

name: Joseph Marie Jacquard
intro: Joseph Marie Jacquard was a French weaver and merchant who lived in the 18th and 19th centuries. He played a crucial role in the development of the earliest programmable loom, which is often referred to as the "Jacquard loom". This device used punched cards to control a sequence of operations. It was an important step in the history of computing hardware because it used a form of binary code and can be considered an early example of a stored-program machine.
achievement: Built and demonstrated the Jacquard loom, a programmable mechanized loom controlled by a tape constructed from punched cards

name: Charles Babbage
intro: Charles Babbage was an English mathematician, philosopher, inventor, and mechanical engineer who is best known for conceiving of the idea of a programmable computer. He designed the "Difference Engine," an automatic mechanical calculator designed to tabulate polynomial functions, and the more complex "Analytical Engine," which was intended to perform any kind of calculation and can be considered an early model for the modern computer.
achievement: Originated the concept of a programmable general-purpose computer; designed the Analytical Engine and built a prototype for a less powerful mechanical calculator.

name: George Boole
intro: George Boole was an English mathematician, educator, philosopher and logician who lived in the 19th century. He worked in the fields of differential equations and algebraic logic, and is now best known as the author of "The Laws of Thought". This work contains Boolean algebra, which forms the basis of all modern computer arithmetic.
achievement: Formalized Boolean algebra, the basis for digital logic and computer science.

name: Ada Lovelace
intro: Ada Lovelace, born as Augusta Ada Byron, was an English mathematician and writer known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She is recognized for writing the world's first machine algorithm for an early computing machine that existed only on paper, thus often referred to as the world's first computer programmer.
achievement: An English mathematician and writer, chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She was the first to recognize that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation, and created the first algorithm intended to be carried out by such a machine. As a result, she is often regarded as the first to recognize the full potential of a "computing machine" and the first computer programmer.

name: Émile Baudot
intro: Émile Baudot was a French telegraph engineer and inventor of the Baudot code, which is used in telegraphy and early digital communications. The Baudot code was a binary 5-bit code, previously used in telegraphy and teletype machines, and is a predecessor to modern character encoding schemes like ASCII and Unicode.
achievement: French telegraphic engineer; patented the Baudot code, the first means of digital communication.[10] The modem speed unit baud is named after him.

name: Ramón Verea
intro: Ramón Verea was a Galician journalist, engineer, and writer, known for inventing a calculator with an internal multiplication table in 1878.
achievement: Designed and patented the Verea Direct Multiplier, the first mechanical direct multiplier.

name: Gottlob Frege
intro: Gottlob Frege was a German philosopher, logician, and mathematician. He is considered one of the founders of modern logic and made significant contributions to the philosophy of language. Among his most notable works is the development of predicate logic, also known as "Fregean logic".
achievement: Extended Aristotelian logic with first-order predicate calculus independently of Charles Sanders Peirce, a crucial precursor in computability theory; also relevant to early work on artificial intelligence, logic programming

name: Charles Sanders Peirce
intro: Charles Sanders Peirce was an American philosopher, logician, mathematician, and scientist. He is known for being one of the founders of pragmatism, an influential philosophical tradition, and for his work in logic, where he developed a form of predicate logic that's been essential to the development of various fields, including computer science. He also contributed to the development of semiotics, the study of signs and symbols.
achievement: Proved the functional completeness of the NOR gate. Proposed the implementation of logic via electrical circuits, decades before Claude Shannon. Extended Aristotelian logic with first-order predicate calculus, independently of Gottlob Frege, a crucial precursor in computability theory. Also relevant to early work on artificial intelligence, logic programming.

name: Herman Hollerith
intro: Herman Hollerith was an American inventor and businessman known for developing a mechanical tabulator based on punched cards to rapidly tabulate statistics from millions of pieces of data. This development was critical in the processing of data for the 1890 U.S. Census. Hollerith's company eventually became part of what is now IBM.
achievement: Widely regarded as the father of modern machine data processing, his invention of the punched card tabulating machine marked the beginning of the era of semiautomatic data processing systems

name: Luitzen Egbertus Jan Brouwer
intro: Luitzen Egbertus Jan Brouwer, generally known as L.E.J. Brouwer, was a Dutch mathematician and philosopher who worked in the early 20th century. He is best known as the founder of the mathematical philosophy of intuitionism, which asserts that the truth of a mathematical statement is a subjective claim that requires construction or proof by the individual asserting it.
achievement: Founded intuitionistic logic, which later came to prevalent use in proof assistants.

name: Percy Ludgate
intro: Percy Edwin Ludgate was an Irish amateur scientist who is known for designing the second analytical engine, a general-purpose Turing-complete computer.
achievement: Charles Babbage in 1843 and Percy Ludgate in 1909 designed the first two Analytical Engines in history. Ludgate's engine used multiplication as its basis (using his own discrete Irish logarithms), had the first multiplier-accumulator (MAC), was first to exploit a MAC to perform division, stored numbers as displacements of rods in shuttles, and had several other novel features, including for program control.

name: Bertrand Russell
intro: Bertrand Russell was a British philosopher, logician, mathematician, historian, writer, and political activist. He is best known for his work in mathematical logic and analytic philosophy, including his role in the development of modern logic and set theory.
achievement: Made contributions to computer science with his work on mathematical logic (example: truth function). Introduced the notion of type theory. He also introduced type system (along with Alfred North Whitehead) in his work, Principia Mathematica.

name: Leonardo Torres Quevedo
intro: Leonardo Torres Quevedo was a Spanish civil engineer, computer scientist, and inventor. He developed the first chess-playing automaton and contributed to the field of modern automation with his inventions of new calculating machines that used electromechanical systems. His machines are considered to be the first digital calculators in history, using discrete variables to do calculations.
achievement: In 1912, Leonardo Torres Quevedo built El Ajedrecista (the chess player), one of the first autonomous machines capable of playing chess. As opposed to the human-operated The Turk and Ajeeb, El Ajedrecista was a true automaton built to play chess without human guidance. It played an endgame with three chess pieces, automatically moving a white king and a rook to checkmate the black king moved by a human opponent. In his work Essays on Automatics, published in 1914, Torres Quevedo formulates what will be a new branch of engineering: automation and designed an electromechanical version of Babbage's Analytical machine which included floating-point arithmetic.

name: William Eccles
intro: William Henry Eccles FRS (1875-1966) was a British physicist and pioneer in radio communication. He advocated for Heaviside's theory on radio wave reflection, invented the term "Diode," and co-patented the flip-flop circuit. Eccles held prestigious positions and made significant contributions to the field of wireless communication and electronic circuit development.
achievement: Patented the Eccles–Jordan trigger circuit,[23] the so-called "bistable flip-flop", a building block of all digital memory cells. Built from vacuum tubes, their concept was essential for the success of the Colossus codebreaking computer.

name: Frank Wilfred Jordan
intro: Frank Wilfred Jordan (1881-1941) was a British physicist known for co-inventing the "flip-flop" circuit in 1918 alongside William Henry Eccles. This circuit became fundamental in electronic memory for computers. Jordan received his education at the Royal College of Science and worked as a lecturer in physics. The flip-flop circuit played a crucial role in storing binary data and became a cornerstone of computer technology.
achievement: Patented the Eccles–Jordan trigger circuit,[23] the so-called "bistable flip-flop", a building block of all digital memory cells. Built from vacuum tubes, their concept was essential for the success of the Colossus codebreaking computer.

name: Vannevar Bush
intro: Vannevar Bush, was an American engineer and inventor who made important contributions to the field of computing. He is most known for his development of the Differential Analyzer, an analog computer that was used to solve differential equations. Additionally, he wrote a seminal essay, "As We May Think," which predicted many aspects of future technology, including hypertext, personal computers, the internet, and search engines. However, his contributions came later in the timeline of the development of computing technology, mainly in the mid-20th century.
achievement: Analogue computing pioneer; originator of the Memex concept, which led to the development of Hypertext

name: Kurt Gödel
intro: Kurt Gödel (1906-1978) was an Austrian mathematician and logician. He is best known for his incompleteness theorems, which had a profound impact on the foundations of mathematics. Gödel's theorems demonstrated that within any formal system, there are true statements that cannot be proven within that system. His work revolutionized the field of mathematical logic and had far-reaching implications for computer science and philosophy. Gödel made significant contributions to the understanding of logic, set theory, and the philosophy of mathematics. His intellectual legacy continues to influence and inspire mathematicians and scientists to this day.
achievement: Proved that Peano arithmetic could not be both logically consistent and complete in first-order predicate calculus. Church, Kleene, and Turing developed the foundations of computation theory based on corollaries to Gödel's work.

name: Rózsa Péter
intro: Rózsa Péter (1905-1977) was a Hungarian mathematician and logician. She made significant contributions to the field of recursive function theory and played a crucial role in the development of computer science. Péter was one of the pioneers of the concept of recursive functions, which are fundamental to computation theory. Her work on formal languages and automata theory also contributed to the advancement of theoretical computer science. Péter's research and publications had a lasting impact on the field, and she is considered one of the notable figures in the history of computer science in Hungary.
achievement: Published a series of papers grounding as a separate area of mathematical research, setting the foundation for theoretical computer science.

name: Akira Nakashima
intro: Akira Nakashima (1908-1970) was a Japanese electrical engineer known for his significant contributions to switching circuit theory. He obtained a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the Imperial University of Tokyo. Nakashima's papers published between 1934 and 1936 laid the foundations for digital circuit design, which had a profound impact on the development of digital computers and modern technology. His work in switching circuit theory is considered comparable to the achievements of Claude Shannon, who presented similar ideas during the same period.
achievement: NEC engineer introduced switching circuit theory in papers from 1934 to 1936, laying the foundations for digital circuit design, in digital computers and other areas of modern technology.

name: Alonzo Church
intro: Alonzo Church (1903-1995) was an influential American mathematician and logician. His work in mathematical logic, particularly lambda calculus, laid the foundations for computation theory and functional programming. Church's contributions had a profound impact on computer science and the understanding of computability, influencing fields such as philosophy and artificial intelligence.
achievement: Made fundamental contributions to theoretical computer science, specifically in the development of computability theory in the form of lambda calculus. Independently of Alan Turing, formulated what is now known as the Church-Turing Thesis and proved that first-order logic is undecidable.

name: Stephen Cole Kleene
intro: Stephen Cole Kleene (1909-1994) was an American mathematician and logician. He made significant contributions to the field of mathematical logic, particularly in the areas of recursion theory and computability. Kleene developed the concept of regular expressions and formalized the notion of recursive functions. His work played a crucial role in the development of theoretical computer science and laid the foundations for modern computability theory. Kleene's research and writings continue to be influential in the field to this day.
achievement: Pioneered work with Alonzo Church on the Lambda Calculus that first laid down the foundations of computation theory.

name: Emil L. Post
intro: Emil Leon Post (1897-1954) was an influential American mathematician and logician. He made notable contributions to mathematical logic, recursion theory, and computer science. Post's work on the Post correspondence problem and formal systems has had a lasting impact on the understanding of computation and the foundations of computer science.
achievement: Developed the Post machine as a model of computation, independently of Turing. Known also for developing truth tables, the Post correspondence problem used in recursion theory as well as proving what is known as Post's theorem.

name: Alan Turing
intro: Alan Turing (1912-1954) was a British mathematician, logician, and computer scientist. He is known for his groundbreaking work in theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. Turing's contributions to the field include the concept of a universal Turing machine and his role in breaking the Enigma code during World War II.
achievement: Made several fundamental contributions to theoretical computer science, including the Turing machine computational model, the conceiving of the stored program concept and the designing of the high-speed ACE design. Independently of Alonzo Church, he formulated the Church-Turing thesis and proved that first-order logic is undecidable. He also explored the philosophical issues concerning artificial intelligence, proposing what is now known as Turing test.

name: George R. Stibitz
intro: George R. Stibitz (1904-1995) was an American mathematician and electrical engineer. He played a significant role in the early development of digital computing, creating the Complex Number Calculator and contributing to the Bell Labs Model I computer. Stibitz's work was instrumental in shaping the future of computing technology.
achievement: Father of modern digital computing and remote job entry. Coined the term "digital". Discovered the reflected binary code known as Gray code. Excess-3 code is named after him as well (Stibitz code).

name: Claude Shannon
intro: Claude Shannon (1916-2001) was an influential American mathematician and electrical engineer known as the "father of information theory." His work in digital circuit design and information theory revolutionized the field and laid the foundations for modern telecommunications, cryptography, and computer science. Shannon's contributions continue to shape technology today.
achievement: Founded information theory, and laid foundations for practical digital circuit design.

name: Konrad Zuse
intro: Konrad Zuse (1910-1995) was a German engineer and computer scientist. He is credited with building the world's first fully functional program-controlled electromechanical computer, the Z3, in 1941. Zuse also developed the first high-level programming language, Plankalkül, and made significant contributions to the field of computer architecture and design.
achievement: Built the first digital freely programmable computer, the Z1. Built the first functional program-controlled computer, the Z3 in 1941. The Z3 already used what later became known as Reverse Polish Notation, and it was proven to be Turing-complete in 1998. Produced the world's first commercial computer, the Z4. Designed the first high-level programming language, Plankalkül.

name: John Atanasoff
intro: John Vincent Atanasoff (1903-1995) was an American physicist and inventor known for his work on the Atanasoff-Berry Computer (ABC). The ABC was the first electronic digital computer, incorporating key elements of modern computing. Atanasoff's contributions were instrumental in the development of computer technology and laid the groundwork for subsequent advancements.
achievement: Built the first electronic digital computer, the Atanasoff–Berry Computer, though it was neither programmable nor Turing-complete.

name: Tommy Flowers
intro: Tommy Flowers (1905-1998) was a British engineer and computer scientist. He is best known for his work in designing and building Colossus, the world's first programmable electronic computer. Colossus played a crucial role in decrypting German codes during World War II. Flowers' innovative design and engineering skills were instrumental in the development of early computers and the advancement of computing technology.
achievement: Designed and built the Mark I Colossus computer, the world's first programmable, digital, electronic, computing devices

name: Max Newman
intro: Max Newman (1897-1984) was a British mathematician and computer scientist. He played a key role in the development of early computers, leading the design of the Colossus computer at Bletchley Park during World War II. Newman's contributions to computer science continued post-war, including establishing the Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester.
achievement: Instigated the production of the Colossus computers at Bletchley Park. After the second world war he established the Computing Machine Laboratory at the University of Manchester where he created the project that built the world's first stored-program computer, the Manchester Baby.

name: J. Presper Eckert
intro: J. Presper Eckert (1919-1995) was an American electrical engineer and computer pioneer. Along with John Mauchly, he co-designed and co-built the ENIAC, the world's first general-purpose electronic digital computer. Eckert's work was instrumental in the development of early computer technology and contributed to the advancement of modern computing.
achievement: With John Mauchly, designed and built ENIAC, the first modern (all electronic, Turing-complete) computer; and UNIVAC I, the first commercially available computer

name: John Mauchly
intro: John Mauchly (1907-1980) was an American physicist and computer scientist. He co-designed and co-built the ENIAC, the world's first general-purpose electronic digital computer, along with J. Presper Eckert. Mauchly's contributions to computer technology and his work on the ENIAC laid the foundation for the development of modern computing.
achievement: With J. Presper Eckert, designed and built the ENIAC, the first modern (all electronic, Turing-complete) computer, and the UNIVAC I, the first commercially available computer. Also worked on BINAC (1949), EDVAC (1949), UNIVAC (1951) with Grace Hopper and Jean Bartik, to develop early stored program computers.

name: Howard Aiken
intro: Howard Hathaway Aiken (1900-1973) was an American physicist and computer scientist. He is best known for designing and developing the Harvard Mark I computer, which was one of the earliest electromechanical computers. Aiken's work on the Mark I laid the groundwork for subsequent advancements in computer technology and played a significant role in the development of modern computing.
achievement: Known for his role in creating the Harvard Mark I computer. His collaboration with IBM, innovations in electromechanical computing, and advocacy for computer science education laid the foundation for modern computing.

name: Allen Coombs
intro: Allen William Mark Coombs (1911-1995) was a British electronics engineer known for his work at the Post Office Research Station, Dollis Hill. He was a principal designer of the Mark II version of the Colossus computer, used for codebreaking at Bletchley Park during World War II. Coombs later worked on the MOSAIC machine and made contributions to optical character recognition. He frequently lectured on pattern recognition and was known for his facial tic.
achievement: Designed and built the Mark II Colossus computers; superseded the Mark I version (which was the world's first digital, electronic computing device)

name: John von Neumann
intro: John von Neumann (1903-1957) was a Hungarian-American mathematician, physicist, and computer scientist. He made pioneering contributions to computer architecture and the concept of stored-program computers. Von Neumann's work in mathematics, physics, and game theory solidified his reputation as one of the greatest intellectuals of the 20th century.
achievement: Formulated the von Neumann architecture upon which most modern computers are based.

name: Harry Huskey
intro: Harry Huskey (1916-2017) was an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computing. He played a significant role in the development of early computers and contributed to the design and implementation of several influential machines, including the SWAC (Standards Western Automatic Computer) and the Bendix G-15. Huskey's work made important contributions to computer architecture and the advancement of computing technology.
achievement: Contributions to the design of early computers including ENIAC, EDVAC, Pilot ACE, EDVAC, SEAC, SWAC, and Bendix G-15 (the latter described as the first personal computer, being operable by one person)

name: Kathleen Booth
intro: Kathleen Booth (1922-2020) was a British computer scientist and mathematician. She is known for her work on the development of assembly language and high-level programming languages. Booth played a key role in the design and implementation of the ARC (Automatic Relay Calculator), one of the earliest computers. Her contributions to computer science and programming languages have had a lasting impact on the field.
achievement: Wrote the first assembly language and designed the assembler and autocode for the first computer systems at Birkbeck College, University of London.

name: Maurice Wilkes
intro: Maurice Wilkes (1913-2010) was a British computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computing. He is best known for designing and building the EDSAC (Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator), one of the world's first practical stored-program computers. Wilkes made significant contributions to computer architecture, programming languages, and operating systems. His work laid the foundation for modern computer systems and had a profound impact on the development of computing technology.
achievement: Built the first practical stored program computer (EDSAC) to be completed and for being credited with the ideas of several high-level programming language constructs.

name: Richard Hamming
intro: Richard Hamming (1915-1998) was an influential American mathematician and computer scientist known for his work in information theory and error-correcting codes. His contributions include the development of Hamming codes, which have played a significant role in error detection and correction in computer systems and communication networks.
achievement: Created the fields of error-correcting code, Hamming code, Hamming matrix, the Hamming window, Hamming numbers, sphere-packing (or Hamming bound), and the Hamming distance established the concept of perfect code.

name: Hedy Lamarr
intro: Hedy Lamarr (1914-2000) was an Austrian-American actress and inventor. She co-invented frequency-hopping spread spectrum technology during World War II, which laid the foundation for modern wireless communication. Lamarr's contribution to telecommunications and her impact on technology have earned her recognition as a pioneering figure in the field.
achievement: At the beginning of World War II, she and composer George Antheil developed a radio guidance system for Allied torpedoes that used spread spectrum and frequency hopping technology to defeat the threat of jamming by the Axis powers. Although the US Navy did not adopt the technology until the 1960s, the principles of their work are incorporated into Bluetooth and GPS technology and are similar to methods used in legacy versions of CDMA and Wi-Fi. This work led to their induction into the National Inventors Hall of Fame in 2014.

name: An Wang
intro: An Wang (1920-1990) was a Chinese-American computer scientist and inventor. He co-founded Wang Laboratories and made significant contributions to computer architecture, particularly in the development of magnetic core memory. His inventions, including the magnetic pulse transfer controlling device, played a pivotal role in the advancement of early computer technology.
achievement: Made key contributions to the development of magnetic core memory.

name: David Caminer
intro: David Caminer (1915-2008) was a British computer pioneer known for his leadership in the development of the Leo computer system, the first computer used for commercial business applications. Caminer's work had a significant impact on the integration of computers into business operations and the advancement of computer technology.
achievement: With John Pinkerton, developed the LEO computer, the first business computer, for J. Lyons and Co

name: Sergei Alekseyevich Lebedev
intro: Sergei Alekseyevich Lebedev (1902-1974) was a notable Soviet computer scientist and engineer. He led the development of the MESM, one of the earliest electronic computers. Lebedev's contributions to the Soviet computer industry and advancements in computer technology have left a lasting impact on the field of computer science.
achievement: Independently designed the first electronic computer in the Soviet Union, MESM, in Kiev, Ukraine.

name: Grace Hopper
intro: Grace Hopper (1906-1992) was a pioneering American computer scientist and naval officer. She developed the first compiler and played a crucial role in the development of early computer systems. Hopper's contributions to programming languages and software standardization have had a profound and lasting impact on the field of computer science.
achievement: Pioneered work on the necessity for high-level programming languages, which she termed automatic programming; wrote the A-O compiler, which heavily influenced the COBOL language

name: David Huffman
intro: David Huffman (1925-1999) was an influential American computer scientist known for developing the Huffman coding algorithm, a widely used method for lossless data compression. His work in information theory and coding theory has had a significant impact on the field of data compression and its applications in various domains.
achievement: Known for inventing Huffman coding, a data compression algorithm widely used today. His algorithm efficiently assigns shorter codes to frequently occurring symbols, revolutionizing data compression and making it a fundamental tool in computer science and information theory.

name: Cuthbert Hurd
intro: Cuthbert C. Hurd (1911-1996) was an American computer scientist and engineer. He played a pivotal role in the development of the IBM System/360 computer system, one of the most influential in history. Hurd's work in computer architecture and system design contributed to the advancement of computing technology.
achievement: Helped IBM develop its first general-purpose computer, the IBM 701

name: Alan Perlis
intro: Alan J. Perlis (1922-1990) was an influential American computer scientist known for his work in programming languages. He was the first recipient of the Turing Award for his contributions to the theory and practice of programming. Perlis' emphasis on clarity and simplicity in programming had a lasting impact on the field.
achievement: On Project Whirlwind, member of the team that developed the ALGOL programming language, and the first recipient of the Turing Award

name: Maurice Karnaugh
intro: Maurice Karnaugh (1924-2019) was an American mathematician and electrical engineer. He is known for his work on Boolean algebra and logic minimization, which led to the development of the Karnaugh map, a graphical method for simplifying logical expressions. Karnaugh's contributions have had a significant impact on digital circuit design and optimization.
achievement: Creator of the Karnaugh map, a variation on Edward Veitch's Veitch chart ; rediscovery of Allan Marquand's much earlier logical diagram used for logic function minimization

name: Richard E. Bellman
intro: Richard E. Bellman (1920-1984) was an influential American mathematician and computer scientist known for his pioneering work in dynamic programming. His research in optimization and control theory laid the foundation for the application of dynamic programming in various fields, revolutionizing decision-making processes and algorithmic approaches.
achievement: American applied mathematician who introduced dynamic programming (1953)

name: Frank Gray
intro: Frank Gray, an American engineer and inventor, is known for his invention of the Gray code, a binary numeral system used in digital communication and information storage. The Gray code, also called reflected binary code, has applications in error detection, data transmission, and hardware systems.
achievement: Physicist and researcher at Bell Labs, developed the reflected binary code (RBC) or Gray code.Gray's methodologies are used for error detection and correction in digital communication systems, such as QAM in digital subscriber line networks.

name: Karen Spärck Jones
intro: Karen Spärck Jones (1935-2007) was a prominent British computer scientist known for her work in information retrieval and natural language processing. She developed the concept of inverse document frequency (IDF), a crucial component of modern search engines. Spärck Jones' contributions revolutionized information retrieval systems and computational linguistics.
achievement: One of the pioneers of information retrieval and natural language processing.

name: Arthur Burks
intro: Arthur Walter Burks (1915-2008) was an American mathematician and computer scientist. He worked alongside John von Neumann on the development of the ENIAC computer, one of the first electronic general-purpose computers. Burks also made significant contributions to the field of symbolic logic and the design of early computer architectures.
achievement: Proposed Reverse Polish Notation with Don Warren and Jesse Wright in 1954, unaware of Konrad Zuse's earlier use of postfix notation in his Z3 in 1941, and later independently reinvented by Friedrich L. Bauer and Edsger W. Dijkstra for use with stacks.

name: Kenneth Iverson
intro: Kenneth Iverson (1920-2004) was a Canadian computer scientist and mathematician. He is best known as the creator of the APL (A Programming Language) programming language. Iverson's work in developing APL introduced innovative concepts, such as array-oriented programming and concise notation, which had a significant impact on the field of programming languages.
achievement: Helped establish and taught the first graduate course in computer science (at Harvard); invented the APL programming language; contributions to interactive computing

name: John Backus
intro: John W. Backus (1924-2007) was an American computer scientist and inventor. He led the team at IBM that developed the programming language FORTRAN, one of the first high-level programming languages. Backus' work in language design and compiler development made programming more accessible and efficient, revolutionizing the field of software development.
achievement: Led the team that created FORTRAN (Formula Translation), the first practical high-level programming language, and formulated the Backus–Naur form that described the formal language syntax.

name: Heinz Zemanek
intro: Heinz Zemanek (1920-2014) was an Austrian computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computer technology. He led the development of the Mailüfterl computer, one of the earliest transistor-based computers. Zemanek also played a key role in the creation of the ALGOL programming language and made significant contributions to computer architecture and software engineering.
achievement: Developed an early fully transistorized computer, the Mailüfterl. Crucial in the creation of the formal definition of the programming language PL/I.

name: Willis Ware
intro: Willis H. Ware (1920-2013) was an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computer security. He played a significant role in the development of computer security policies and standards. Ware served as the chief scientist at the RAND Corporation and made significant contributions to the field of cybersecurity.
achievement: Co-designer of JOHNNIAC. Chaired committee that developed the Code of Fair Information Practice and led to the Privacy Act of 1974. Vice-chair of the Privacy Protection Study Commission.

name: Noam Chomsky
intro: Noam Chomsky is an influential American linguist, philosopher, cognitive scientist, and political activist. Known for his theories on generative grammar and the concept of universal grammar, Chomsky has made significant contributions to the study of language and has been a prominent critic of U.S. foreign policy and media propaganda.
achievement: Made contributions to computer science with his work in linguistics. Developed Chomsky hierarchy, directly impacting programming language theory and other branches of computer science.

name: Allen Newell
intro: Allen Newell (1927-1992) was an American computer scientist and cognitive psychologist. He co-developed the Logic Theorist, the first artificial intelligence program, and later worked on the development of the General Problem Solver. Newell also made significant contributions to cognitive psychology, particularly in the field of human problem-solving and decision-making.
achievement: Together with J. C. Shaw and Herbert Simon, the three co-wrote the Logic Theorist, the first true AI program, in the first list-processing language, which influenced LISP.

name: Herbert A. Simon
intro: Herbert A. Simon (1916-2001) was an American economist, political scientist, and cognitive psychologist. He co-developed the General Problem Solver and, together with Allen Newell, pioneered the field of artificial intelligence. Simon's work in decision-making and problem-solving has had a lasting impact on cognitive science, economics, and computer science. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1978.
achievement: A political scientist and economist who pioneered artificial intelligence. Co-creator of the Logic Theory Machine and the General Problem Solver programs.

name: Wolfgang Händler
intro: Wolfgang Händler (1920-1998) was a German mathematician and computer scientist known for his pioneering work in various fields. As a professor at Leibniz University Hannover and the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, he made significant contributions to automata theory, parallel computing, artificial intelligence, man-machine interfaces, and computer graphics. Händler's work has had a lasting impact on the advancement of these areas of study.
achievement: Pioneering work on automata theory, parallel computing, artificial intelligence, man-machine interfaces and computer graphics; one of the lead architects of the TR 4 [de] supercomputer; invented Händler diagrams for logic function minimization; devised the Erlangen Classification System [de] (ECS) for parallel computers

name: Edward J. McCluskey
intro: Edward J. McCluskey (1929-2016) was an American electrical engineer and computer scientist. He made significant contributions to the field of digital logic design, particularly in the area of logic synthesis and switching theory. McCluskey's work on simplifying logic circuits and developing methods for optimizing Boolean functions has had a profound impact on the design of digital systems.
achievement: Fundamental contributions that shaped the design and testing of digital systems, including the first algorithm for digital logic synthesis, the Quine-McCluskey logic minimization method.

name: Russell Gray Kirsch
intro: Russell Gray Kirsch (1929-2020) was an American computer scientist and inventor. He is known for developing the first digital image scanner and the first digital image using a computer in 1957. Kirsch's contributions to digital imaging and his invention of the pixel have had a profound impact on the field of computer graphics and image processing.
achievement: Whilst working for the National Bureau of Standards (NBS), Kirsch used a recently developed image scanner to scan and store the first digital photograph.His scanned photo of his three-month-old son was deemed by Life magazine as one of the "100 Photographs That Changed The World.”

name: John McCarthy
intro: John McCarthy (1927-2011) was an American computer scientist and cognitive scientist. He is known for coining the term "artificial intelligence" and pioneering research in the field. McCarthy developed the Lisp programming language, which became a major tool for AI research. His contributions laid the foundations for modern AI and symbolic programming.
achievement: Known for creating the LISP programming language, a significant development in artificial intelligence (AI) research. He coined the term "artificial intelligence" and made contributions to time-sharing systems and formal logic. McCarthy received the Turing Award for his groundbreaking work in computer science.

name: Saul Rosen
intro: Saul Rosen (1922-1991) was an American computer science pioneer known for designing the software for the Philco Transac S-2000, the first transistor-based computer. He also contributed to programming language design, particularly influencing the ALGOL language. Rosen played a key role in establishing the Association for Computing Machinery and co-founded the journal Annals of the History of Computing.
achievement: Designed the software of the first transistor-based computer. Also influenced the ALGOL programming language.

name: Seymour Ginsburg
intro: Seymour Ginsburg (1927-2004) was an American computer scientist and mathematician. He made significant contributions to formal languages and automata theory. Ginsburg developed the concept of "context-free languages" and contributed to the theory of pushdown automata. His work has had a lasting impact on the field of theoretical computer science and programming language design.
achievement: Proved "don't-care" circuit minimization does not necessarily yield optimal results; proved that the ALGOL programming language was context-free (linking formal language theory to the problem of compiler writing); invented AFL Theory

name: Fred Brooks
intro: Frederick P. Brooks Jr. (born 1931) is an American computer scientist and software engineer. He is best known for managing the development of IBM's System/360 mainframe computer and for writing the influential book "The Mythical Man-Month." Brooks' work has greatly influenced the field of software engineering and project management. He received the Turing Award in 1999.
achievement: Manager of IBM System/360 and OS/360 projects; author of The Mythical Man-Month.

name: J. C. R. Licklider
intro: J.C.R. Licklider (1915-1990) was an American psychologist and computer scientist. He is considered one of the pioneers of the field of computer science. Licklider was instrumental in the development of ARPANET, the precursor to the internet, and he played a key role in promoting the concept of human-computer interaction and the idea of a global computer network. His visionary ideas laid the foundation for the digital age we live in today.
achievement: Began the investigation of human–computer interaction, leading to many advances in computer interfaces as well as in cybernetics and artificial intelligence.

name: Peter Naur
intro: Peter Naur (1928-2016) was a Danish computer scientist and Turing Award recipient. He made significant contributions to the development of programming languages, particularly with the development of the programming language ALGOL 60. Naur's work emphasized the importance of precise language specification and formal methods in software development.
achievement: Edited the ALGOL 60 Revised Report, introducing Backus-Naur form

name: Paul Baran
intro: Paul Baran (1926-2011) was a Polish-born American engineer and pioneer in the field of computer networking. He is credited with the development of packet switching, a fundamental concept behind modern computer networks. Baran's work laid the foundation for the creation of the Internet as we know it today.
achievement: One of two independent inventors of the concept of digital packet switching used in modern computer networking including the Internet. Published a series of briefings and papers about dividing information into "message blocks" and sending them over distributed networks (1960–1964).

name: Friedrich L. Bauer
intro: Friedrich L. Bauer (1924-2015) was a German computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computer science. He made significant contributions to the development of programming languages, compilers, and operating systems. Bauer was also known for his work on formal methods in software engineering and his contributions to the field of cryptography.
achievement: Proposed the stack for expression evaluation, with Edsger W. Dijkstra. Influential in establishing computer science as an independent discipline of science; coined the term software engineering. Contributed to numerical analysis, fundamentals of interpretation and translation of programming languages, systematics of program development, program transformation, and cryptology.

name: Leonard Kleinrock
intro: Leonard Kleinrock (born 1934) is an American computer scientist known for his pioneering work on packet switching theory, which laid the foundation for the development of the Internet. He played a key role in the creation of ARPANET, the precursor to the Internet, and is considered one of the fathers of the Internet.
achievement: Pioneered the application of queueing theory to model delays in message switching networks in his Ph.D. thesis in 1961–1962, published as a book in 1964. He later published several of the standard works on the subject. In the early 1970s, he applied queueing theory to model the performance of packet switching networks. This work played an influential role in the development of the ARPANET, the precursor to the Internet. He supervised many graduate students who worked on the communication protocols for internetworking which led to the Internet. His theoretical work on hierarchical routing in the late 1970s with student Farouk Kamoun remains critical to the operation of the Internet today.

name: C. A. R. Hoare
intro: C. A. R. Hoare (born 1934), also known as Tony Hoare, is a British computer scientist and Turing Award recipient. He is best known for his development of the Quicksort algorithm and the concept of Hoare logic, which is widely used in program verification. Hoare's work has significantly influenced the field of computer science and software engineering.
achievement: Developed the formal language Communicating Sequential Processes (CSP), Hoare logic for verifying program correctness, and Quicksort; fundamental contributions to the definition and design of programming languages

name: Wesley A. Clark
intro: Wesley A. Clark (born 1927) is an American computer scientist and engineer. He played a vital role in the development of computer systems and parallel computing. Clark co-designed the groundbreaking IBM Stretch supercomputer and contributed to the creation of the Burroughs B5000 computer system, which introduced innovative concepts like virtual memory and hardware support for multitasking.
achievement: Designed LINC, the first functional computer scaled down and priced for individual users (1963). Many of its features are considered prototypes of essential elements of personal computers.

name: Ole-Johan Dahl
intro: Ole-Johan Dahl (1931-2002) was a Norwegian computer scientist and co-creator of the programming language Simula. He made significant contributions to object-oriented programming and software engineering. Dahl's work on Simula, the first language to support object-oriented programming concepts, had a profound impact on the development of modern programming languages and software engineering practices.
achievement: With Kristen Nygaard, invented the proto-object oriented language SIMULA

name: Kristen Nygaard
intro: Kristen Nygaard (1926-2002) was a Norwegian computer scientist and co-creator of the programming language Simula. He made significant contributions to the field of object-oriented programming and software engineering. Nygaard's work on Simula, along with Ole-Johan Dahl, revolutionized programming language design and laid the foundation for modern object-oriented programming languages.
achievement: With Ole-Johan Dahl, invented the proto-object oriented language SIMULA.

name: Jean E. Sammet
intro: Jean E. Sammet (1928-2017) was an American computer scientist and software engineer. She played a crucial role in the development of the programming language COBOL and was heavily involved in its standardization. Sammet also made significant contributions to programming language theory and software engineering methodologies, leaving a lasting impact on the field.
achievement: Developed the FORMAC programming language. She was also the first to write extensively about the history and categorization of programming languages in 1969, and became the first female president of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1974.

name: Douglas Engelbart
intro: Douglas Engelbart (1925-2013) was an American computer scientist and inventor. He is best known for inventing the computer mouse and pioneering several key concepts in human-computer interaction. Engelbart's groundbreaking work at the Stanford Research Institute contributed to the development of graphical user interfaces, hypertext, and collaborative tools, shaping the future of computing.
achievement: Best known for inventing the computer mouse, with Bill English; pioneer of human–computer interaction whose Augment team developed hypertext, networked computers, and precursors to GUIs

name: Marvin Minsky
intro: Marvin Minsky (1927-2016) was an American cognitive scientist and computer scientist. He co-founded the field of artificial intelligence (AI) and made significant contributions to the development of AI, cognitive psychology, and robotics. Minsky's work on neural networks, perception, and machine learning has had a profound impact on the field of AI.
achievement: Co-founder of Artificial Intelligence Lab at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, author of several texts on AI and philosophy. Critic of the perceptron.

name: Ivan Sutherland
intro: Ivan Sutherland (born 1938) is an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of computer graphics. He is known for his groundbreaking work on Sketchpad, the first graphical user interface, and for his development of the "Sutherland-Hodgman" algorithm for polygon clipping. Sutherland's contributions have had a profound impact on computer graphics and human-computer interaction.
achievement: Author of Sketchpad, the ancestor of modern computer-aided drafting (CAD) programs and one of the early examples of object-oriented programming.

name: Pier Giorgio Perotto
intro: Pier Giorgio Perotto (1930-2020) was an Italian engineer and computer scientist. He is credited with inventing the Programma 101, the first commercially available personal computer. Perotto's work on the Programma 101 revolutionized the computing industry, making computers accessible to a wider audience and paving the way for the future of personal computing.
achievement: Computer designer for Olivetti, designed one of the first electronic programmable calculators, the Programma 101

name: Seymour Cray
intro: Seymour Cray (1925-1996) was an American electrical engineer and computer architect. He is considered one of the pioneers in supercomputer design. Cray founded Cray Research and developed a series of supercomputers, including the Cray-1 and Cray-2, which set new standards for computing power and speed. His innovations greatly advanced the field of high-performance computing.
achievement: Designed a series of computers that were the fastest in the world for decades; and founded Cray Research, which built many of them; credited with creating the supercomputer industry

name: Joseph Weizenbaum
intro: Joseph Weizenbaum (1923-2008) was a German-American computer scientist and a pioneer in the field of artificial intelligence. He is best known for creating the ELIZA computer program, which simulated conversation and highlighted the social and ethical implications of AI. Weizenbaum's work explored the relationship between humans and intelligent machines.
achievement: One of the fathers of modern artificial intelligence. Creator of the ELIZA program using natural language processing to emulate conversations with a psychologist.

name: James Cooley
intro: James Cooley (born 1926) is an American mathematician and computer scientist. He is known for his co-development of the Cooley-Tukey FFT algorithm, a fast algorithm for computing the discrete Fourier transform. Cooley's work in signal processing and algorithm design has had a significant impact on various fields, including telecommunications and image processing.
achievement: With John W. Tukey, Known for co-developing the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm. His work revolutionized signal processing by enabling efficient computation of the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT), impacting a wide range of applications in fields like audio, image processing, and telecommunications.

name: Donald Davies
intro: Donald Davies (1924-2000) was a Welsh computer scientist and one of the pioneers of packet switching, a fundamental technology underlying the internet. He co-invented the concept and led the development of the NPL network, one of the earliest packet-switched networks. Davies' work laid the foundation for modern computer networking and revolutionized data communication.
achievement: One of two independent inventors of the concept of digital packet switching used in modern computer networking including the Internet.Conceived of and named the concept for data communication networks (1965–66).Many of the wide-area packet-switched networks of the 1970s, including ARPANET, were similar "in nearly all respects" to his original 1965 design.

name: John W. Tukey
intro: John W. Tukey (1915-2000) was an American mathematician and statistician. He made significant contributions to the fields of exploratory data analysis, fast Fourier transform (FFT), and statistical computing. Tukey's work revolutionized data analysis methods and statistical thinking, and he coined the term "bit" in computing. He received numerous honors for his contributions.
achievement: With James Cooley, created the fast Fourier transform. He invented the term "bit".

name: Corrado Böhm
intro: Corrado Böhm was an Italian computer scientist and mathematician. He made significant contributions to the field of programming languages and formal methods. Böhm is known for his work on lambda calculus, term rewriting systems, and his development of the Böhm tree, which is used in the study of computational complexity.
achievement: Known for his contributions to theoretical computer science. He developed the SKI combinator calculus, made advancements in lambda calculus, and contributed to formal language theory. His work influenced programming languages and computability theory.

name: Stephen Cook
intro: Stephen Cook (born 1939) is a Canadian computer scientist and mathematician. He is best known for his development of the concept of NP-completeness and the Cook-Levin theorem, which provided a foundation for understanding the difficulty of solving computational problems. Cook's work has had a profound impact on theoretical computer science and algorithms.
achievement: Formalized the notion of NP-completeness, inspiring a great deal of research in computational complexity theory

name: Ken Thompson
intro: Ken Thompson (born 1943) is an American computer scientist and co-creator of the Unix operating system and the C programming language. He played a key role in the development of the original Unix system, including the creation of important tools and utilities. Thompson's work has had a lasting impact on the field of operating systems and software development.
achievement: Created the Unix operating system, the B programming language, Plan 9 operating system, the first machine to achieve a Master rating in chess, and the UTF-8 encoding at Bell Labs and the Go programming language at Google.

name: Dennis Ritchie
intro: Dennis Ritchie (1941-2011) was an American computer scientist and co-creator of the Unix operating system and the C programming language. His contributions to the development of Unix and C have had a profound impact on modern operating systems and software development, shaping the foundations of the digital world we live in today.
achievement: With Ken Thompson, pioneered the C programming language and the Unix computer operating system at Bell Labs.

name: Edsger W. Dijkstra
intro: Edsger W. Dijkstra (1930-2002) was a Dutch computer scientist and mathematician. He made significant contributions to the field of computer science, particularly in the areas of algorithms, programming languages, and software engineering. Dijkstra is known for his development of the shortest path algorithm and his influential work on structured programming and concurrency control.
achievement: Made advances in algorithms; pioneered and coined the term structured programming; invented the semaphore; famously suggested that the GOTO statement should be considered harmful

name: Betty Holberton
intro: Betty Holberton (1917-2001) was an American computer scientist and one of the original programmers of the ENIAC, one of the first general-purpose electronic computers. She made significant contributions to the development of computer programming and software engineering, including the creation of the first software application for the UNIVAC I computer. Holberton's work paved the way for the advancement of computing technology.
achievement: One of the original ENIAC programmers and contributed to the development of the COBOL programming language. She invented the C-10 coding system and advocated for women in computing, leaving a lasting impact on the field of computer science.

name: Adriaan van Wijngaarden
intro: Adriaan van Wijngaarden (1916-1987) was a Dutch mathematician and computer scientist. He is best known for his work in the development of the ALGOL programming language and the influential concept of "grammars." Van Wijngaarden's contributions to programming languages and compiler design have had a lasting impact on the field of computer science.
achievement: Developer of the W-grammar first used in the definition of ALGOL 68

name: Donald Knuth
intro: Donald Knuth (born 1938) is an American computer scientist and mathematician. He is known for his pioneering work in algorithms and the art of computer programming. Knuth is the author of the multi-volume book series "The Art of Computer Programming," which is considered a fundamental resource in the field of computer science.
achievement: Wrote The Art of Computer Programming and created TeX. Coined the term "analysis of algorithms" and made major contributions to that field, including popularizing Big O notation.

name: Per Brinch Hansen
intro: Per Brinch Hansen (1938-2007) was a Danish computer scientist and software engineer. He made significant contributions to concurrent programming and operating systems. Hansen developed the monitor concept, which is widely used in concurrent programming languages. His work influenced the design of operating systems and played a key role in the advancement of parallel computing.
achievement: Developed the RC 4000 multiprogramming system, which introduced the concept of an operating system kernel and the separation of policy and mechanism; effectively the first microkernel architecture.Co-developed the monitor with Tony Hoare, and created the first monitor implementation. Implemented the first form of remote procedure call in the RC 4000,and was first to propose remote procedure calls as a structuring concept for distributed computing.

name: Edgar F. Codd
intro: Edgar F. Codd (1923-2003) was a British computer scientist and mathematician. He is best known for his pioneering work in the field of relational databases and the invention of the relational model for database management systems. Codd's contributions have had a profound impact on the field of data management and database technology.
achievement: Proposed and formalized the relational model of data management, the theoretical basis of relational databases

name: James H.Wilkinson
intro: James H. Wilkinson (1919-1986) was a British mathematician and computer scientist. He made significant contributions to numerical analysis and numerical linear algebra. Wilkinson developed algorithms and techniques for solving problems in numerical mathematics, including matrix eigenvalue problems. His work has had a lasting impact on scientific computing and numerical analysis.
achievement: Research in numerical analysis to facilitate the use of the high-speed digital computer, having received special recognition for his work in computations in linear algebra and "backward" error analysis.

name: Niklaus Wirth
intro: Niklaus Wirth (born 1934) is a Swiss computer scientist known for his contributions to programming languages and software engineering. He designed several influential programming languages, including Pascal and Modula-2. Wirth emphasized simplicity, clarity, and reliability in language design, and his work has had a significant impact on the field of programming language development.
achievement: Designed the Pascal, Modula-2 and Oberon programming languages.

name: Frances E. Allen
intro: Frances E. Allen (1932-2020) was an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of compiler optimization. She became the first woman to receive the Turing Award for her fundamental contributions to the theory and practice of optimizing compiler techniques. Allen's work significantly advanced the field of programming languages and compiler design.
achievement: Developed bit vector notation and program control-flow graphs; first female IBM Fellow (1989); first female recipient of the ACM's Turing Award (2006).

name: Alan Kay
intro: Alan Kay (born 1940) is an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of personal computing. He is known for his work on object-oriented programming, graphical user interfaces, and the development of the Smalltalk programming language. Kay's contributions have greatly influenced modern computing and user interface design.
achievement: Pioneered many ideas at the root of object-oriented programming languages; led the team that developed Smalltalk; made fundamental contributions to personal computing

name: Lynn Conway
intro: Lynn Conway (born 1938) is an American computer scientist and transgender activist. She made significant contributions to computer architecture and VLSI design methodologies. Conway developed the generalized dynamic instruction handling technique, which revolutionized the design of modern computer processors. She is also a prominent advocate for transgender rights and visibility in the tech industry.
achievement: Superscalar architecture with multiple-issue out-of-order dynamic instruction scheduling

name: Federico Faggin
intro: Federico Faggin (born 1941) is an Italian-American engineer and inventor. He is known for his role in the development of the first commercial microprocessor, the Intel 4004, and for his work on the MOS Technology 6502 microprocessor. Faggin's contributions have played a pivotal role in the advancement of computer technology.
achievement: Known for designing the world's first commercially available microprocessor, the Intel 4004. He co-founded Zilog and developed the popular Z80 microprocessor. Faggin's contributions revolutionized the field of computing and semiconductor technology, shaping the modern digital age.

name: Margaret Hamilton
intro: Margaret Hamilton (born 1936) is an American computer scientist and systems engineer. She led the software engineering division of the Apollo space program and developed the on-board flight software for the Apollo spacecraft. Hamilton's work was crucial for the success of the Moon landing missions and has had a lasting impact on software engineering and systems development.
achievement: Developed the concepts of asynchronous software, priority scheduling, end-to-end testing, and human-in-the-loop decision capability, such as priority displays which then became the foundation for ultra-reliable software design

name: Per Martin-Löf
intro: Per Martin-Löf (born 1942) is a Swedish logician, mathematician, and philosopher. He is known for his foundational work in mathematical logic, particularly in the development of intuitionistic type theory. Martin-Löf's contributions to the field of logic and constructive mathematics have had a significant impact on computer science, programming language theory, and formal verification.
achievement: Published an early draft on the type theory that many proof assistants build on.

name: Masatoshi Shima
intro: Masatoshi Shima (born 1943) is a Japanese electrical engineer and computer architect. He was a key member of the team that developed the Intel 4004, the world's first commercially available microprocessor. Shima's contributions to microprocessor design have been instrumental in shaping the field of computer architecture and advancing the capabilities of modern computing devices.
achievement: Designed the Intel 4004, the first commercial microprocessor,as well as the Intel 8080, Zilog Z80 and Zilog Z8000 microprocessors, and the Intel 8259, 8255, 8253, 8257 and 8251 chips.

name: Richard Stallman
intro: Richard Stallman (born 1953) is an American software developer and free software advocate. He founded the Free Software Foundation and initiated the GNU Project, aiming to create a free and open-source operating system. Stallman has been instrumental in promoting the principles of software freedom, open collaboration, and user autonomy in the digital world.
achievement: Stallman launched the GNU Project in September 1983 to create a Unix-like computer operating system composed entirely of free software. With this, he also launched the free software movement.

name: Gary Kildall
intro: Gary Kildall (1942-1994) was an American computer scientist and entrepreneur. He developed the CP/M operating system, which became one of the most popular operating systems for early microcomputers. Kildall's work laid the foundation for modern operating systems, and he played a key role in the early development of the personal computer industry.
achievement: Introduced the theory of data-flow analysis in optimizing compilers (global expression optimization, Kildall's method). Worked on instruction set emulators (INTERP), found an innovative software relocation method (page boundary relocation), and laid the foundation to the concepts of binary recompilation (XLT86). Developed the first high-level programming language and compiler for microcomputers (PL/M) and the first mainstream operating system for microcomputers (CP/M). Invented the concept of a hardware abstraction layer called the BIOS, with both conceptually laying the foundation to all DOS-based operating systems on personal computers. Worked on diskette track buffering schemes, read-ahead algorithms, virtual disk drives, and file system caching. Developed the first computer interface for video disks and pioneered CD-ROM file systems, introducing the first encyclopedia for computers (The Electronic Encyclopedia). Pioneered a modular PBX communication system integrating land-lines with mobile phones (Intelliphone) and to remotely connect with home appliances.

name: André Truong Trong Thi
intro: André Trương Trọng Thi (1936–2005) was a Vietnamese-French computer engineer credited as the "father of the personal computer." He co-created the Micral N microcomputer in 1973, utilizing an Intel 8008 processor. The Micral N is recognized as one of the first commercial microcomputers and played a pivotal role in the development of personal computing technology.
achievement: Invention of the Micral N, the earliest commercial, non-kit personal computer based on a microprocessor.

name: François  Gernelle
intro: François Gernelle is a French inventor and computer engineer known for his contributions to the development of the Micral N, one of the world's first commercial microcomputers. Alongside André Trương Trọng Thi, Gernelle co-created the Micral N in 1973, which utilized an Intel 8008 processor and played a significant role in the advancement of personal computing.
achievement: Invention of the Micral N, the earliest commercial, non-kit personal computer based on a microprocessor.

name: Charles Bachman
intro: Charles Bachman (born 1924) is an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of database management systems. He developed the Integrated Data Store (IDS), an influential network model database management system. Bachman's work on data structures and database design has greatly influenced the field of data management and laid the foundation for modern database systems.
achievement: Renowned for his work in database management systems. He developed the Integrated Data Store (IDS), introduced the Bachman Diagram and Data Structure Diagram (DSD), and received the Turing Award for his significant contributions to the field.

name: Jacek Karpinski
intro: Jacek Karpinski (born 1934) is a Polish mathematician and computer scientist. He made significant contributions to the field of computational complexity theory, particularly in the study of polynomial-time algorithms and circuit complexity. Karpinski's work has advanced our understanding of the inherent complexity of computational problems and has had a lasting impact on theoretical computer science.
achievement: Developed the first differential analyzer using transistors; developed one of the first machine-learning algorithms for character and image recognition; invented of one of the first minicomputers, the K-202

name: Charles P. Thacker
intro: Charles P. Thacker (1943-2017) was an American computer scientist and hardware designer. He played a key role in the development of personal computing and graphical user interfaces. Thacker co-invented the Xerox Alto, one of the first computers to feature a graphical user interface. His contributions have had a lasting impact on computer design and human-computer interaction.
achievement: Pioneering design and realization of the Xerox Alto, the first modern personal computer, and in addition for his contributions to the Ethernet and the Tablet PC.

name: Edwin Catmull
intro: Edwin Catmull (born 1945) is an American computer scientist and co-founder of Pixar Animation Studios. He is known for his contributions to computer graphics and computer animation. Catmull's work in developing algorithms and techniques for rendering and modeling has revolutionized the field of computer animation and has earned him numerous accolades and awards.
achievement: Computer generated imagery (CGI) and 3D graphics pioneer who developed texture mapping, the Catmull-Clark subdivision surface algorithm (with Jim Clark), and the Catmull-Rom spline (with Raphael Rom. Former vice president of Industrial Light & Magic and co-founder of and former president of Pixar

name: Elizabeth Feinler
intro: Elizabeth Feinler is an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of internet technology. She played a key role in the development of the ARPANET, the precursor to the internet, and was instrumental in establishing the first internet address registry. Feinler's work has had a lasting impact on the growth and organization of the internet.
achievement: Lead team that defined a simple text file format for Internet host names, which became the Domain Name System; her group became the naming authority for the top-level domains of .mil, .gov, .edu, .org, and .com

name: Leslie Lamport
intro: Leslie Lamport (born 1941) is an American computer scientist known for his contributions to distributed systems and concurrent computing. He developed the Paxos algorithm for achieving consensus in a distributed system, which has become a fundamental building block of distributed computing. Lamport has received numerous awards for his influential work in computer science.
achievement:
Formulated algorithms to solve many fundamental problems in distributed systems (e.g. the bakery algorithm).
Developed the concept of a logical clock, enabling synchronization between distributed entities based on the events through which they communicate. Created LaTeX.

name: Jim Gray
intro: Jim Gray (1944-2007) was an American computer scientist and database researcher. He made significant contributions to the field of database management systems, including the development of transaction processing and data warehousing techniques. Gray received the Turing Award for his seminal contributions to database and transaction processing research.
achievement: Innovator in database systems and transaction processing implementation

name: Gerard Salton
intro: Gerard Salton (1927-1995) was an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of information retrieval. He developed the Vector Space Model, a foundational concept in modern information retrieval systems. Salton's work revolutionized the field and laid the groundwork for techniques used in search engines and text mining applications today.
achievement: A pioneer of automatic information retrieval, who proposed the vector space model and the inverted index.

name: Philip Rubin
intro: Philip Rubin is an American cognitive scientist and neuroscientist. He has made significant contributions to the study of auditory perception, speech recognition, and the neurobiology of language. Rubin has served in various leadership roles in academia and research organizations, working to advance our understanding of the human brain and cognition.
achievement: Developed pioneering computational speech synthesis systems for use in the experimental study of speech perception and production, including articulatory synthesis and sinewave synthesis. Also designed the HADES signal processing system, a predecessor of MATLAB.

name: Whitfield Diffie
intro: Whitfield Diffie (born 1944) is an American cryptographer and one of the pioneers of public-key cryptography. He, along with Martin Hellman, introduced the concept of asymmetric encryption, which revolutionized secure communication over the internet. Diffie's work laid the foundation for modern cryptographic protocols and played a crucial role in ensuring digital privacy and security.
achievement: Fundamental contributions to modern cryptography. Diffie and Hellman's groundbreaking 1976 paper "New Directions in Cryptography introduced the ideas of public-key cryptography and digital signatures, the foundation of security protocols used on the Internet today.

name: Martin Hellman
intro: Martin Hellman (born 1945) is an American cryptographer and one of the pioneers of public-key cryptography. Alongside Whitfield Diffie, he introduced the concept of asymmetric encryption, which transformed the field of cryptography. Hellman's contributions have been vital in ensuring secure communication, digital privacy, and the development of cryptographic protocols widely used today.
achievement: Fundamental contributions to modern cryptography. Diffie and Hellman's groundbreaking 1976 paper, "New Directions in Cryptography,Introduced the ideas of public-key cryptography and digital signatures, the foundation for security protocols on the Internet today.

name: Michael O. Rabin
intro: Michael O. Rabin (born 1931) is an Israeli computer scientist and mathematician. He made significant contributions to theoretical computer science, particularly in the fields of algorithms, automata theory, and cryptography. Rabin co-developed the famous Miller-Rabin primality test and received the Turing Award for his influential work in the field of computer science.
achievement: The joint paper "Finite Automata and Their Decision Problems,"which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines, which has proved to be an enormously valuable concept. Their (Scott & Rabin) classic paper has been a continuous source of inspiration for subsequent work in this field.

name: Dana Scott
intro: Dana Scott (born 1932) is an American mathematician and computer scientist. He is known for his contributions to the field of theoretical computer science, particularly in the area of semantics of programming languages. Scott's work on lambda calculus and denotational semantics has had a significant impact on the foundations of programming languages and mathematical logic.
achievement: The joint paper "Finite Automata and Their Decision Problems," which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines, which has proved to be an enormously valuable concept. Their (Scott & Rabin) classic paper has been a continuous source of inspiration for subsequent work in this field.

name: Leonard Adleman
intro: Leonard Adleman (born 1945) is an American computer scientist and molecular biologist. He is known for his role in developing the RSA encryption algorithm, one of the most widely used encryption methods. Adleman's work on computational biology and DNA computing has also contributed to advancements in the field of biotechnology and molecular computing.
achievement: Ingenious contribution and making public-key cryptography useful in practice.

name: Ron Rivest
intro: Ron Rivest (born 1947) is an American cryptographer and computer scientist. He is best known as one of the co-creators of the RSA encryption algorithm, along with Adi Shamir and Leonard Adleman. Rivest has made significant contributions to cryptography, computer security, and algorithm design, earning numerous awards and honors for his work.
achievement: Ingenious contribution and making public-key cryptography useful in practice.

name: Adi Shamir
intro: Adi Shamir (born 1952) is an Israeli cryptographer and computer scientist. He is one of the co-creators of the RSA encryption algorithm, along with Ron Rivest and Leonard Adleman. Shamir has made significant contributions to the field of cryptography, particularly in the areas of secret sharing and the development of various cryptographic protocols.
achievement: Ingenious contribution and making public-key cryptography useful in practice.

name: Vint Cerf
